channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Open Source: Outpouring of Grief and Anger as Pakistani Activist Is Gunned Down
item.description: Sabeen Mahmud was killed just after hosting a seminar with critics of how Pakistan’s military fights a separatist insurgency in Baluchistan.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Activists Say Both North Korea and South Korea Approve Women’s Peace Walk
item.description: The women conceived the walk across the Demilitarized Zone to punctuate their desire for a permanent peace treaty to replace the armistice that halted — but technically never ended — the 1950-53 Korean War.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Amid Errors, Obama Publicly Wrestles With Drones’ Limits
item.description: The strike that killed two hostages by mistake has underscored that there is no such thing as near certainty in war, even one waged with precision instruments like drones.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: “We don’t take this work lightly,” President Obama said Friday to intelligence officials who set the standards for drone strikes.

item.title: China, in Suspending Woman’s Death Sentence, Acknowledges Domestic Abuse
item.description: The ruling means that after two years of good behavior, the sentence of Li Yan, who killed her husband, will be commuted to life in prison. Later, it may be reduced further.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yan, 35 in this photograph, was first sentenced to death in the 2010 killing of her husband.

item.title: Gunmen Kill Arts Advocate in Pakistan After Human Rights Event
item.description: Sabeen Mahmud was shot shortly after hosting an event on human rights abuses in Baluchistan Province at the popular arts center she ran, The Second Floor.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SABA IMTIAZ

item.title: Armenia, on Day of Rain and Sorrow, Observes 100th Anniversary of Genocide
item.description: President Serzh Sargsyan described the killing of Armenians as “unprecedented in terms of volume and ramifications” at that point in history.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: The Tsitsernakaberd Memorial Complex — the country's main monument to the roughly 1.5 million people killed — during a commemoration ceremony for the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide in Yerevan on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: ISIS Kills an Army Commander
item.description: Fighters from the Islamic State group ambushed an Iraqi Army convoy on Friday with a bulldozer packed with explosives.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Man Is Arrested for Flying Drone Onto Japanese Leader’s Office Roof, Reports Say
item.description: The discovery of the drone on Wednesday had baffled officials, especially after it was found to be carrying trace amounts of radioactive material.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: American Naval Force Off Yemen Gets Credit After Iranian Convoy Turns Away
item.description: Pentagon officials said the deployment — and Iran’s apparent response — had lowered tensions in the regional proxy war between Tehran and Saudi Arabia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Syria Remains Silent on Intelligence Official’s Death
item.description: Reports had simmered for weeks that Brig. Gen. Rustom Ghazali had been severely beaten in an internal government dispute.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Arctic Council Meeting Starts Amid Russia Tensions
item.description: As the council holds its biennial summit meeting Friday in northern Canada, its mission is being strained by the broad deterioration of relations with Russia.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: Andrew Kramer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russia is drilling a natural gas well near the Arctic Ocean. President Vladimir V. Putin is focusing heavily on the region, where climate change has intensified economic and political competition.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia Says ISIS Helped a Militant Who Killed Police Officers
item.description: The man accused of killing two police officers in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, received guns, cash and instructions from the Islamic State, Saudi officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Former Guantánamo Inmate Is Granted Bail in Canada
item.description: A Canadian court ordered that Omar Khadr, a Canadian who was captured in Afghanistan in 2002 at age 15, be released on bail pending an appeal of his conviction by an American military tribunal.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: U.N. Refugee Official Calls Situation in Syria and Iraq ‘Unsustainable’
item.description: António Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, and other officials painted an increasingly grim picture of the crisis in the region.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Turkey’s Focus Is Elsewhere on Anniversary of Armenian Genocide
item.description: As Armenians in Istanbul sought an apology for the killing of 1.5 million people, the government commemorated the victory at the Battle of Gallipoli in World War I.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Terrorist Cell May Have Sought to Attack the Vatican, Italian Officials Say
item.description: A prosecutor said an investigation had revealed that a Pakistani man who was in Rome in March 2010 was “described as a kamikaze.”
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Chile Volcano Prompts New Evacuations, Flights to Argentina Cancelled
item.description: The Chilean volcano Calbuco, which erupted without warning on Wednesday, was still puffing out ash and smoke on Friday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Ash settled on a rooftop in Ensenada, southern Chile, on Friday as the Calbuco volcano continued to erupt. Chilean officials evacuated 4,000 people from the immediate area and the ash cloud drifted across the Andes, causing airports to close in Argentina.

item.title: Drone Strikes on Al Qaeda Are Said to Take Toll on Leadership in Pakistan
item.description: Strikes like the one that killed two Western hostages have forced militant leaders to regroup and seek shelter, analysts say.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: The site of a drone attack in 2008 that killed at least six people in a Pakistani tribal region regarded as a safe haven for militants from Al Qaeda and Taliban.

item.title: Migration Crisis Puts Europe’s Policy Missteps Into Focus, Experts Say
item.description: Europe is struggling with how to save lives on the sea, prosecute human smugglers and deal with the causes of the migrant surge closer to their source.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants were photographed and logged as they disembarked from an Italian Coast Guard ship on Friday at a port in Catania, Sicily.

item.title: Eurozone Ministers Admonish Greece for Slow Progress on Overhauls
item.description: Finance leaders criticized Athens for moving too slowly to improve the economy and take steps they see as necessary to avoid a default.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Dmitris Sulzics/F64 Photo Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Yanis Varoufakis, center, the finance minister of Greece, with other eurozone finance ministers in Riga, Latvia on Friday.
